thread.title: Fantasy Football 2015: 13 things owners must watch for Week 6
thread.title_full: Fantasy Football 2015: 13 things owners must watch for Week 6

author: Des Bieler
title: Fantasy Football 2015: 13 things owners must watch for Week 6
text:
By Des Bieler October 15 at 3:09 PM Follow @DesBieler The Post's fantasy football experts, Gene Wang and Des Bieler, discuss the major takeaways from Week 5 including Jamaal Charles, Calvin Johnson, Aaron Rodgers, Blake Bortles and waiver wire options. (Thomas Johnson/The Washington Post) 
Cardinals vs. Steelers 
People who have been waiting all this time for Martavis Bryant to make his season debut will likely get it, but they shouldn’t expect much, particularly if Roethlisberger doesn’t play. Still, it will be nice to see the rangy WR out there, and his deep-ball skills could be put to use right away if Pittsburgh finds itself in catch-up mode. In 2014, Bryant averaged 21.1 yards per reception. 
Chiefs vs. Vikings Will Charcandrick West become the lead back in Kansas City? (Charlie Riedel/AP Photo) 
Here’s hoping some readers took heed of my warning in this space last week that Knile Davis might not actually be the handcuff for Charles. Charcandrick West was the subject of frantic waiver claims and massive FAAB bids from coast to coast, and now his new owners will get a chance to see if the RB was worth it. Or will this be more of a committee, with Davis getting valuable goal-line looks? 
Redskins vs. Jets 
A lot of people picked up the Jets’ defense this week to play against the Redskins, and just as many will drop it next week, with New York set to visit New England. But for those who can spare an extra roster spot, the Jets would be a sneaky add at that point, because after the Pats, a unit that just got Sheldon Richardson back will have a mouth-watering slate through Week 14 (Raiders, Jags, Bills, Texans, Dolphins, Giants, Titans). 
[ Week 6 Start/Sit: Best bets to score big ] 
Bears vs. Lions 
The Bears are hoping Alshon Jeffery gets back on the field for the first time since Week 1, but Marquess Wilson owners could hardly be blamed for wanting Jeffery to take his sweet time and make sure that calf is fully healed. All Wilson has done in the past two weeks as Chicago’s default No. 1 WR is grab 12 balls for 165 yards and a score. His moment in the sun, though, may be brief. 
Broncos vs. Browns 
C.J. Anderson got his shot last year when the two guys above him on the depth chart proved unable, either by ineffectiveness or injury, to get the job done. Ronnie Hillman was one of those guys, and now both he and Anderson are struggling. That should make No. 3 RB Juwan Thompson a name worth knowing, except that a hamstring injury could be costing him a huge opportunity. 
Texans vs. Jaguars 
Pricey free-agent acquisition Julius Thomas made his long-awaited debut for the Jags last week after a preseason hand injury, but he didn’t do much. With a game under his belt, though, Thomas can be expected to start contributing to fantasy lineups as the team’s pass-catching TE. As it happens, Bortles’s injury may have him looking to hit underneath routes more than usual. 
[ Stock Watch: Dump your Detroit Lions ] 
Dolphins vs. Titans 
Campbell is a former TE, so Jordan Cameron owners can hope that the Dolphins’ new head coach has better ideas on how to wring some more production from that position. Cameron has seen his share of targets, averaging seven per game, but he’s turned them into just 12 catches for 170 yards and zero TDs. There’s still time for the athletic player to blossom into a TE1. 
Panthers vs. Seahawks 
It’s probably too much to expect Carolina to run the ball well at Seattle, but the division of labor among its RBs could be interesting. Setting aside Cam Newton’s extensive usage in the ground game, Jonathan Stewart dominated the work in the first three games, but in the team’s most recent contest, rookie backup Cameron Artis-Payne got eight carries to Stewart’s 10. 
Chargers vs. Packers 
Antonio Gates is now 19th among TEs in standard-league scoring, which is kind of amazing, considering he has played all of one game. That game, in which he emerged from a four-game suspension to snag nine catches for 92 yards and two TDs on the Steelers, did come against the second-most generous defense to TEs, so we’ll see if he can keep it up versus the Pack’s stingier unit. 
[ Trade talk: Make a sneaky deal for Sammy Watkins ] 
Bengals vs. Bills 
Jeremy Hill began last season as Giovani Bernard’s backup and then literally ran away with the starting job, so that could happen again, right? Well, sort of the opposite has happened this year, except that Hill is still starting games. But Bernard has been easily the more effective RB, averaging 5.5 yards per carry to Hill’s 3.0. If Bernard (one TD) starts getting work near the goal line, Hill’s value will really dry up. 
Ravens vs. 49ers 
Baltimore placed Lorenzo Taliaferro on injured reserve with a foot injury, meaning that Javorius “Buck” Allen moves up to the backup RB spot. Allen may actually be more than that right away, as Justin Forsett is dealing with his own foot injury. Even if Forsett plays, it’s a reminder that Allen is worth consideration for a roster spot, especially given that Taliaferro was getting some usage in the red zone. 
Patriots vs. Colts 
Ahmad Bradshaw is 29, which sounds ancient for an RB until you consider that Frank Gore is 32. Now Bradshaw is the young pup nipping at Gore’s heels, having been signed by the Colts this week after proving that the leg he broke last November is fully healed. Bradshaw was a useful player for Indy the past couple of seasons, averaging 4.7 yards per carry, and he might turn into a useful flex play in PPR leagues. 
Giants vs. Eagles 
Isn’t Philadelphia supposed to have a high-tempo offense? So far, Chip Kelly’s squad is 18th in plays run per game (64.0), meaning that there isn’t as big of a pie for DeMarco Murray and Ryan Mathews to share. While Murray is pretty much assured of a solid workload, Mathews owners are hoping his fine play (5.0 YPC) lets him carve out a respectable role, and it’s even possible he becomes the goal-line back. Des writes for the Early Lead and the D.C. Sports Bog, scouring the Web to bring readers items of interest, both serious and amusing. He also covers fantasy football, as well as fitness topics for the MisFits. sports Success! Check your inbox for details. You might also like: Please enter a valid email address Sign Up
